lazy criminal sexually immoral feeble minded degenerate & non-white poors, bc socialism doesn't categorize ppl based on deserving or non-deserving. It just advocates for assisting folks--either through the gov or through the workers owning the means of production etc 17/

So fast forward a few hundred years & you get a toxic mix of xenophobia, racism, American Exceptionalism, poormesia, ableism, & anti-labor sentiment, all of which combine to paint socialism as some kind of apocalyptic Satanic world ending ideology 15/

take advantage of it, & that the "deserving" poor might prove themselves "undeserving" by coming to rely on gov. aid instead of working hard & not being lazy. That's why the workhouses in Britain & the US were so bad. To use a modern phrase the cruelty was the point. 14/

& the "undeserving" poor--criminals, beggars, prostitutes, ppl w/a bunch of kids who were assumed to be sexually immoral (& later "feeble minded" bc ableism). SO, when they did sometimes support relief efforts, there was always the concern that the "undeserving" poor would 13/

hostile to them. They v. much made a distinction between the "deserving" poor, ie ppl who worked & were poor bc...they never really explained this, just stated that these ppl deserved help bc poor but not criminal, sexually "immoral" etc--12/

Also bc social Darwinism (applying Darwin's principles of survival of the fittest to ppl) coupled w/Protestant Work Ethic (ie if you work hard God will bless you & if you're poor that's clearly a moral judgement from God) most liberals were distrustful of poor ppl or outright 11/
bc of that view, most liberals (known as neoliberals now) were super wary of any gov. program that involved gov control of the economy, bc they saw that as messing w/nature. 10/

& a hands off approach to the economy.  This goes back to the Enlightenment when ppl like Adam Smith said that the economy was guided by the "invisible hand" & gov. "interference" would be messing w/natural laws, kinda like someone intervening in a nature documentary 9/

Along w/all the racism & xenophobia that the US has, we also have a really long history of being anti poor, that, IMO, we inherited from the British liberal (economic liberals not social really) tradition.  Liberals in the historic sense were v. much in favor of individualism 8/

Also along the way somehow socialism & communism got equated, & both got applied indiscriminately to the labor movement, & then to any kind of public safety net.  For example, Social Security in the 30s got decried as socialist & evil by FDR's critics, as did lit. every other 6/
Hence the concern over immigration & discussions of threats to the US way of life. Now tbf the US has always taken issue w/immigrants but it ramps up in the 1880s end sidebar 2

& honestly, I know OP has disabilities too, but idk. I feel like the system assumes profs are abled & NT & the students expect that too & when we’re not we end up a/competing access needs & it just sucks.

I just know I feel confused & overloaded bc I’m already dealing w/trying to monitor my tone, facial expressions & every single word I say so I don’t offend my (mainly) NT students. I’m masking so hard that trying not to react to sounds is impossible

Also, sudden sounds break my brain. So if I’m lecturing & student A is giggling & whispering to Student B, I hear that, & every thought just leaves my head & all I can think is find the sound & get it to stop, I’m not really registering that it’s a person at that point

Bc that’s what happened every time I’ve tried in the past. My job gives me accommodations for my vision but idk if they’d give me flexible deadlines for turning grades in, which either means I gotta have deadlines or I’m near killing myself grading everything at the last minute

idk how to make a course w/allowance of tech & flexible deadlines & etc that doesn’t result in me existing in sensory hell, no one paying attention or passing exams & me grading a semester’s worth of work in the last week bc everyone has extensions & there are no due  dates
& every semester in every class I have someone do it, in a way that feels hostile/bullying, so I doubt disclosing my sensory issues would go any better.

& every time I have someone decide Ive gone on too long during the last five mins of class or I’m talking too long about a marginalized group & they’ll start clicking a pen at me & it’s all I can do not to meltdown & maybe they’re stimming but I always ask them not to do that

& I know from personal experience that disclosing the particulars of my visual disability just encouraged students to exploit that & I suspect that they’d do the same if I disclosed my autism bc I disclose my issues w/clicking pens

so ppl listened to music/videos, shared things w/each other + whisper chatted throughout class & it became sensory hell bc I can’t tune out sounds & so I was constantly telling ppl to be quiet or turn off their music & idk how to be accessible to the students w/out hurting myself

Genuine ? How can I do this & not have it backfire? I’m autistic & a professor & when I allowed computers & phones in class for everyone the classes became inaccessible FOR ME bc my attempts at being fair made the students feel they could blow off class https://t.co/49mxm9sOYH

It isn't quite the same as the Nazis' rhetoric around PWD but it's similar and IMO calling it eugenics is, speaking strictly from a historical perspective, accurate bc eugenics isn't always just focused on reproduction. Sometimes it means disabled ppl should die bc economics too.

Apparently without realizing or caring that that just sends the message that we're not only expendable but that our deaths are used to comfort healthy/abled ppl bc they're not us, won't ever be us, so they're safe.
Now the CDC isn't saying let's all kill disabled ppl but they are absolutely using deaths of disabled ppl to say see only sick/disabled ppl will die so all the healthy ppl can chill

disabled ppl were a supposed drain on the economy and so letting them die/outright murdering them was seen as the right thing to do for the economic situation in Germany. They were seen as a drain on society & expendable.

AND by framing PWD as unproductive burdens on society. The German term in English is lives unworthy of life but useless eaters was another one they were fond of. In the case of A. T4, it wasn't concerns over disabled ppl having more disabled babies it was concerns that

They did that not by focusing on the supposed need to keep disabled ppl from reproducing--they'd done that w/an earlier law, the law for the prevention of hereditary diseases--earlier in the 1930s. W/A. T4 they framed it as both preventing the supposed suffering of PWD
The Nazis got support for a program known as Akton (action or operation) T4, which was the systemic murder by CO2 poisoning or death by starvation, of ppl w/disabilities

1st, in the US, eugenists were primarily concerned with reproduction--limiting who could & couldn't have children. That wasn't the case w/the Nazis & understanding why is IMO important to understanding why ppl are calling this eugenics now

I feel like the above + difficulty caused by auditory processing issues w/accents, + possible reading/comprehension/speech difficulties when encountering unfamiliar words & similar issues, don’t get talked about by the disability community bc 15/

makes me, a traumatized autistic white woman, feel like I can’t talk about my experiences bc the default is to assume bad fath & not disability, especially on social media, & I wish it wasn’t that way. 13/

& it’s not me manipulating them or trying to deflect the situation or get sympathy or anything else implied in that phrase, it is an out of control fear response bc raised voices to me = you’re going to die, painfully & horribly, & Idk why but I have always felt like this 11/
I’m just gonna say this & if ppl get mad they get mad. If someone yells at me I will cry, & I don’t care what marginalized or not marginalized group they belong to, 10/

sets off my, something unspeakable is going to happen fear PLUS my oh no this kid is gonna get spanked & everybody will act like it’s normal/deserved & I’ll get mocked/told off for being too sensitive if I react with distress fear, 6/

that I grew up witnessing infants/toddlers punished for crying/babbling/the shriek stage all little kids seem to go through just added an extra level of oh no to an already terrifying experience so now crying kids 5/

existential dread & fear I can’t really articulate, but it’s comparable to watching a horror movie & knowing some unknown terrible thing is about to happen, but multiplied by the largest number you can think of, plus one. 4/

I cannot tell the difference between stern, firm & I’m so mad I am literally going to beat you to death with my bare hands. They all sound the *exact same* in my head. They all equal immediate, extreme, threats of fatal violence. Shrieking children fill me with a level of 3/

do whatever I was told by whomever I was told no matter what, so it felt like taking back some power.  This has been my response  every time I assert myself or get someone to  do something I want or apologize or anything like I’m finally the one in charge/in the  parent role 8/
